elements.title: Merger Agreement with IAA and Securities Purchase Agreement Overview

data.value: In February 2023, we closed a securities purchase agreement with Starboard Value LP and certain of its affiliated funds to issue and sell in a private placement $485.0 million of newly-issued shares of senior preferred stock and $15.0 million of common shares.
The newly-issued preferred equity securities provide rights, preferences and privileges senior to those of common stock, with annual dividends of 5.5% of the aggregate principal amount.
Expected decrease in net income attributable to common stockholders due to cumulative dividends rights of preferred shares.
The company entered into a merger agreement with IAA, with covenants including conducting business in the ordinary course.
If the Merger Agreement is terminated, a termination fee of $189.0 million would be required.
Entered into a debt commitment letter for a $2.8 billion bridge loan facility.
Funding the cash portion of IAA acquisition through cash, credit facilities, and proceeds from debt securities.
Issuing equity securities may cause shareholder dilution.

elements.title: Income Tax Expense and Net Income
Financial Performance Metrics (in U.S. dollars $000's, except percentages)

data.value: This table presents financial performance metrics for what appears to be an A&M segment over three years (2020-2022). The data shows strong growth in 2022, with total revenue increasing by 22% to $1,535,220,000. Notable highlights include a 37% increase in inventory sales revenue and a 25% increase in fees revenue in 2022. Service revenue, combining commissions and fees, grew by 12% in 2022 compared to 2021. The overall trend shows accelerated growth in 2022 compared to more modest growth in 2021.

elements.title: Notes to the Consolidated Financial Statements

data.value: The Company classifies a share-based payment award as an equity or liability payment based on the substantive terms of the award and any related arrangement.
The cost of equity-settled share-based payment arrangements is recorded based on the estimated fair-value at the grant date and charged to earnings over the vesting period.
The Company has a senior executive performance share unit (PSU) plan and an employee PSU plan that provides for the award of PSUs to certain senior executives and employees.
The cost of PSUs granted is measured at the fair value of the underlying PSUs at the grant date.
The Company assesses the probability of satisfying the market condition in its estimate of fair value.
The Company has a senior executive RSU plan and an employee RSU plan that provides for the award of RSUs.
The cost of RSUs granted is measured at the fair value of the underlying RSUs based on the fair value of the Company’s common shares at the grant date.
The Company has three stock option compensation plans that provide for the award of stock options to selected employees.
The Company maintains other share unit compensation plans that vest over a period of up to three years after grant.
Measured at fair value at the date of grant and re-measured at each reporting date.
The fair value of the awards is expensed over the respective vesting period.
Liability-classified share unit liabilities due within 12 months are presented in trade and other liabilities.
Includes lease and non-lease components; operating leases recognized based on right-of-use assets.
Lease payments are recognized on a straight-line basis over the lease term.
Portfolio approach for similar lease terms and incremental borrowing rate for present value calculations.

Number of organizations activated on IMS. An organization is considered activated on IMS when a customer has signed an annual multi-channel contract and has an IMS instance setup to allow for equipment to be directed to one of our transaction solutions digitally.

This metric calculates the total number of bids received for a lot divided by the total number of lots sold. GovPlanet business metrics are excluded from this metric as management reviews industrial equipment auction metrics excluding GovPlanet.

A single asset to be sold, or a group of assets bundled for sale as one unit. Low value assets are sometimes bundled into a single lot, collectively referred to as 'small value lots'. GovPlanet business metrics are excluded from this metric as management reviews industrial equipment auction metrics excluding GovPlanet.

data.value: Revenues are comprised of service revenue and inventory sales revenue as part of A&M activities, recognized when control is transferred to customers.
Includes revenue from auction activities, commissions from sales, listing services, refurbishment, logistical services, financing, appraisals, data and software subscriptions.
Revenue is measured at the fair value of the consideration received, shown net of value-added tax and duties.
Commissions represent a percentage earned on gross proceeds from equipment sold at auction.
Revenue recognized upon completion of auction with buyer invoicing, payment collection, and remittance to sellers after deducting commissions and fees.

elements.title: Notes to the Consolidated Financial Statements

data.value: Revenue is recognized upon final acceptance of the winning bid through auction sales.
Commission revenue is recognized net of commission owed to third parties.
Provisions for disputes are included in the commission revenue estimate.
Losses from guarantee contracts are recorded upon completion of the auction.
Includes fees for refurbishment, logistical services, etc.

elements.title: Notes to the Consolidated Financial Statements

data.value: Significant Accounting Policies (continued) (g) Leases (continued) Sale and Leaseback

The transfer of the asset shall not be accounted for as a sale if the leaseback would be classified as a finance lease or a sales-type lease. If the transaction does not qualify for sale and leaseback accounting treatment, the asset is not derecognized.
Derivative instruments are recorded at fair value. Unrealized gains and losses on derivatives not designated in a hedging relationship are recorded as operating income.

Fair value is the exit price that would be received to sell an asset or paid to transfer a liability in an orderly transaction. The Company measures financial instruments at fair value at each balance sheet date.

data.value: This section provides information about accounting policies related to income tax expenses and earnings per share.
Current tax expense is determined based on taxable profit for the period, adjustments to tax payable, and recognizes differences between accounting and tax bases.
Deferred tax assets and liabilities account for temporary differences, non-capital loss, and tax credits using enacted tax rates.
Basic EPS calculated by net income attributable to stockholders divided by the weighted average number of shares; diluted EPS considers dilutive stock options.
The Company matches employee contributions to retirement plans as mandated by local authorities.
Advertising costs are expensed immediately and included in service and administrative expenses.

data.key: Tax on Capital Gains for U.S. Resident Holders
data.value: A U.S. Resident Holder will not be subject to tax under the Canadian Tax Act for capital gains unless common shares are taxable Canadian property.
Common shares constitute 'taxable Canadian property' if certain ownership and value conditions are met.
Dividends paid to U.S. Resident Holders will generally incur a 25% Canadian withholding tax, which may be reduced under tax treaties.
Withholding tax rate is 15% under the Convention for beneficial owners, or 5% if owning at least 10% voting shares.
No tax consequence for the Company

The pendency of our acquisition of IAA or our failure to complete such acquisition could have a material adverse effect on our business, results of operations, financial condition and stock price.
We may experience difficulties in integrating our operations with those of IAA and realizing the expected benefits of the acquisition.
We will incur a substantial amount of debt to complete the acquisition of IAA, which could have a material adverse effect on our business, cash flows and financial condition.
Significant costs have been incurred and are expected to be incurred in connection with the consummation of the acquisition of IAA.
Damage to our reputation could harm our business.
We may incur losses as a result of our guarantee and inventory contracts and advances to consignors.
The availability and performance of our technology infrastructure, including our websites, is critical to our business and continued growth.
Consumer behavior is rapidly changing, and if we are unable to successfully adapt to consumer preferences, our financial performance could be adversely affected.
We rely on data provided by third parties, the loss of which could limit the functionality of certain platforms.
Government regulation of the Internet and e-commerce is evolving, and unfavorable changes could substantially harm our business.
If our ability to safeguard IT systems is compromised, we may incur significant reputational harm or legal exposure.
Future expenses may increase significantly due to licenses, laws and regulations.
Losing the services of key personnel could materially affect our business.
Failure to maintain safe sites could materially affect our business.
Income and commodity tax amounts may significantly differ from expectations.
Substantial international operations expose us to foreign exchange rate fluctuations.
An investment in our common stock involves a high degree of risk.
The proposed acquisition of IAA may adversely affect our business and financial condition.
Completion is subject to various conditions including shareholder approvals.
Litigation could delay or prevent the acquisition.
A termination fee of $189 million is payable under certain conditions.
Announcement of acquisition could disrupt business and operations.
Restrictions on business activities while the agreement is in effect.

elements.title: Risk Factors Related to Inventory and Technology Infrastructure

data.key: Risk of Limited Control Over Rolling Stock Assets
data.value: We have limited ability to control rolling stock assets and may not attract buyers for non-rolling stock inventory.

data.key: Impact of Technology Performance on Business
data.value: The performance and reliability of our technology infrastructure are critical for business growth and reputation.
Our systems may experience service interruptions due to various reasons including cybersecurity events.

data.key: Ineffective internal control over financial reporting
data.value: Could result in errors in financial statements, reduce investor confidence, and adversely impact stock price.
We are required to furnish a report by management on the effectiveness of our internal control.
During the fiscal year ended December 31, 2020, two material weaknesses were identified and remediated by December 31, 2021.
We may identify additional material weaknesses in the future.
Failure to maintain internal control could lose investor confidence in the accuracy of our financial reports.
We could be subject to sanctions by the NYSE, SEC or other regulatory authorities.

data.value: Goodwill represents the excess of the purchase price of an acquired enterprise over the fair value assigned to the assets acquired and liabilities assumed in a business combination. Goodwill is tested annually for impairment.
Deferred financing costs represent the unamortized costs incurred on the issuance of the Company’s long-term debt. Amortization is provided over the term of the facility.

data.value: The trusted global marketplace for insights, services and transaction solutions for commercial assets and vehicles.
Deliver the best customer experience in the industry: We're trusted, and we make it easy.
Deliver the best employee experience: Make it easy to deliver an amazing customer experience!
Implement a modern architecture for the business on which we can scale and grow profitably: Position ourselves for sustainable growth & efficiency!
Coordinate growth around a single, integrated inventory management system: The core of everything we do.
Accelerate growth: Opportunities too big to wait!
We strive to create the best workplace for all employees.
Encourages open dialogue and robust communications.
Fixing processes and technology for the benefit of employees and customers.
Transitioning to cloud-based microservices for flexibility.
Integrates and tracks inventory data for customers.
Piloting improved business processes to enhance customer experience.
Distinct multi-channel brand solutions for buyers and sellers.
Live unreserved onsite auctions, with live online simulcast.
Online marketplace for selling and buying used equipment.
Online marketplace offering multiple price and timing options.
Online marketplace for the sale of government and military assets.
Confidential, negotiated sale of large equipment.
Ritchie Bros. connects buyers and sellers through a global network of auction sites, enhancing liquidity and market pricing.
Focus on long-term relationships, treating customers as friends and tailoring solutions to their needs.
Ritchie Bros. offers a comprehensive suite of equipment disposition solutions and value-added services.
Investment in data science, providing insights and services based on the largest used equipment transaction dataset.
Utilization of machine learning for price indexes and strategic operational decisions.
